title: Upper Part of a Tabernacle for the Holy Sacrament
description: This relief represents the upper of two surviving panels from the altar of the Holy Sacrament in the Roman basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore (the second panel remains in the church). Dismantled in 1573, the altar was one of a number of improvements in the church instituted by Cardinal Guillaume d’Estouteville, archpriest of Santa Maria Maggiore during much of the 15th century. As his name implies, Isaia came from a family of stone carvers in Pisa and was active in Rome from 1428. He produced a number of tombs and altars there, although the majority no longer survive. Between 1455 and 1458, he collaborated on one of the grandest sculptural projects of the century, the Arch of Alfonso I of Aragon in Naples.
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Potter Palmer
publication_history:
Art Institute of Chicago, Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago: Report of the Year 1938, 33, 4 (1939), pl. 9.

Meyric R. Rogers, “The Robert Allerton Wing,” Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago, 34 (1940), pp. 5-6.

Ulrich Middeldorf, “The Tabernacle of S. Maria Maggiore,” Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago 38, 1 (1944), pp. 6–10; reprinted Ulrich Middeldorf, Raccolta di Scritti, that is Collected Writings II: 1939–1973, Specimen 4 (Florence, 1980), pp. 55–59.

Valentino Martinelli, "Donatello e Michelozzo a Roma (II)," Commentari, 9 (1958), p. 21 n. 34. 

Hans Caspary, “Ancora sui tabernacoli eucaristici del Quattrocento,”Antichità viva, 3, 5 (1964), pp. 29-30, 35.

Hans Caspary, Das Sakramentstabernakel in Italien bis zum Konzil von Trient.  Gestalt, Ikonographie und Symbolik, kultische Funktion (Munich, 1964), pp. 32-33, 35, 38-39, 41, 136 n. 79, 198 ( ill.).

Allen Wardwell and Mildred Davison, “Three Centuries of the Decorative Arts in Italy,” Apollo 84 (1966), pp. 179-180, fig. 2.

Hanno-Walter Kruft and Magne Malmanger, “Der Triumphbogen Alfonsos in Neapel.  Das Monument und seine politische Bedeutung,” Institutum Romanum Norvegiae Acta 6 (1975), pp. 270-271, fig. 116.

Francesco Negri Arnoldi, "Isaia da Pisa e Pellegrino da Viterbo" in Il Quattrocento a Viterbo, exh. cat. (Viterbo, Museo Civico, 1983), pp. 338, 340 n. 34.

Meredith Jane Gill, “A French Maecenas in the Roman Quattrocento: The Patronage of Guillaume d’Estouteville (1439-1483),” PhD. dissertation, Princeton University, 1992, pp. 87, 127-28 n. 11, figs. 3-5.

Sible de Blaauw, Cultus et Decor.  Liturgia e architettura nella Roma tardoantica e medieval: Basilica Salvatoris, Sanctae Mariae, Sancti Petri (Vatican City, 1994), p. 372.

Carlo La Bella, “Scultori nella Roma di Pio II (1458-1464).  Considerazioni su Isaia da Pisa, Mino da Fiesole e Paolo Romano,” Studi Romani 43 (1995), pp. 29-30.

"Isaia da Pisa" in The Dictionary of Art, vol. 16 (London, 1996), p. 67.

Francesco Cagliotti, “Su Isaia da Pisa: Due ‘Angeli reggicandelabro’ in Santa Sabina all'Aventino e l’altare eucaristico del Cardinal d’Estouteville per Santa Maria Maggiore,” Prospettiva, nos. 89-90 (1998), pp. 129, 130, 132-4, 137, 139, 146, 148-52, figs. 15, 21 a-c.

Francesco Caglioti, “Un medaglione neroniano d’Isaia da Pisa a Philadelphia e due altre aggiunte al catalogo dello scultore” in Arte collezionismo conservazione: Scritti in onore di Marco Chiarini, ed. Miles L. Chappell, Mario Di Giampaolo, Serena Padovani (Florence, 2004), p. 162, fig. 4. 

Francesco Caglioti, “Altari eucaristici scolpiti del primo Rinascimento: qualche caso maggiore” in Lo Spazio e il culto. Relazioni tra edificio ecclesiale e uso liturgico dal XV al XVI secolo, ed. Jörg Stabenow (Venice 2006), p. 82.

Carlo La Bella, “Isaia da Pisa, Mino da Fiesole e gli scultori toscani” in Il ‘400 a Roma. La rinascita delle arti da Donatello a Perugino, ed. Maria Grazia Bernardini and Marco Bussagli, vol. 1, exh. cat. Museo del Corso, Rome (Milan, 2008), p. 197.
.
provenance_text: Part of the Altar of the Holy Sacrament commissioned by Cardinal Guillaume d’Estouteville for the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore, Rome [Middeldorf 1944]; dismantled by 1573 [see Caglioti 1998].  Possibly Émile Molinier, Paris (died 1906) [according to Middeldorf 1944 and 1980, though the basis for this statement is unclear].  Alessandro Imbert, Rome, by 1920 [according to note added to the incoming receipt of Jan. 28, 1938 in registrar's office]; sold to Potter Palmer, II and Pauline Kohlsaat Palmer, Chicago, 1920 [see receipt cited above]; given by them to the Art Institute, 1938.

input: Upper Part of a Tabernacle for the Holy Sacrament
